pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.2: At that time Devadatta went to see Kokālika, Kaṭamodakatissaka, Khaṇḍadeviyā-putta, and Samuddadatta, and he said to them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.4: “Come, let’s create a schism in the Order of the ascetic Gotama, a break in transmission.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.6: “The ascetic Gotama has great supernormal powers.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.8: “Well, let’s go to the ascetic Gotama and request five things:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.9: ‘Venerable Sir, in many ways the Master praises fewness of wishes, contentment, erasing of defilements, ascetic practices, being inspiring, reduction in things, and being energetic.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.10: And there are five things that lead to just that.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.11: It would be good, Venerable Sir:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.12: If the monks were stayed in the wilderness for life,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.13: and whoever stays near a village would commit an offense
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.14: If they were alms-collectors for life,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.15: and whoever accepts an invitation would commit an offense
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.16: If they were rag-robe wearers for life,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.17: and whoever accepts a robe from a lay person would commit an offense
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.18: If they dwelt at the foot of a tree for life,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.19: and whoever takes shelter would commit an offense
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.20: If they did not eat fish or meat for life,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.21: and whoever does would commit an offense.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.22: The ascetic Gotama won’t allow this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.23: We’ll then be able to win people over with these five points.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.24: Kokālika said, “It might be possible to create a schism in the Order with these five points,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.25: for people have confidence in austerity.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.1: Devadatta and his followers then went to the Master, bowed, and sat down,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.12: Those who wish may stay in the wilderness, and those who wish may live near a village.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.13: Those who wish may be alms-collectors, and those who wish may accept invitations.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.14: Those who wish may be rag-robe wearers, and those who wish may accept robes from lay people.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.15: I have allowed a resting place at the foot of a tree for eight months of the year, as well as fish and meat which are pure in three respects:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.16: one has not seen, heard, or suspected that the animal was specifically killed to feed a monastic.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.18: “The Master doesn’t allow the five points,” and he was glad and elated. He rose from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Master with his right side toward him, and left with his followers.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.19: Devadatta then entered Rājagaha and won people over with the five points, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.33: “The ascetic Gotama doesn’t agree to them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.34: but we practice in accordance with them.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.1: The foolish people with little faith and confidence said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.2: “These Sakyan ascetics are practicing asceticism and they live for the sake of erasing defilements.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.3: But the acetic Gotama lives in luxury and has chosen to live in abundance.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.4: But the wise people who had faith and confidence complained and criticized Devadatta,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.5: “How can Devadatta act to create a schism in the Order of the Master?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.6: The monks heard the criticism of those people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.7: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized him
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.10: After rebuking Devadatta in many ways, they told the Master. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.11: He said, “Is it true, Devadatta, that you are acting to create a schism in the Order, a break in transmission?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.14: Foolish man, how can you act to create a schism in the Order?
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.15: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.16: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.17: ‘If a monk pursues schism in a united Order or persists in taking up a legal issue conducive to schism, the monks should say to him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.18: “Venerable, don’t pursue schism in the united Order or persist in taking up a legal issue conducive to schism.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.19: Stay with the Order, for a united Order—in concord, in harmony, having a joint recitation—lives in comfort.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.21: If that monk still continues as before, the monks should press him up to three times to make him stop.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.22: If he then stops, all is well.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.23: If not, he commits an offense entailing suspension.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.68: For one who commits the offense entailing suspension, the offense of wrong conduct and the serious offenses are annulled.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.70: … Therefore, too, it is called “an offense entailing suspension.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:3.1.1: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, and he perceives it as legitimate, but he does not stop, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:3.1.2: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, but he is unsure if it is, and he does not stop, he commits an offense entailing suspension.
